Abstract

For the past few years, the storytelling research domain has raised the interest of several researchers from different areas (such as interactive drama, computer games, intelligent learning environment etc.), mainly because stories are an important vehicle to structure the human knowledge and past experience, and even to help people to behave in a social context. In this paper, we present a storytelling approach, which is based on the premise that story and narrative may emerge from characters’ interactions during the creation activity, but such characters may either act autonomously or be controlled by children. Since we position our research in an educational context, we argue that in such creation activities children’s thoughts and needs must be respected and contribute directly to the achievement of the story. Therefore, children should be provided with some support and guidance directives to help them to better understand and reflect on the role-taking situations they experience during such activity. To prove the validity of our approach we developed a generic architecture—Support And Guidance Architecture (SAGA). SAGA aims not only to provide support and guidance to children during the story telling activities, by combining the roles of a dynamic script writer and a drama manager, but also to provide such services to already existing story creation applications. To illustrate this, we have integrated SAGA with Teatrix, a collaborative virtual environment for story creation, and an evaluation study was conducted in order to find the impact of SAGA in children’s storytelling activities.

Introduction

“Could you tell me a story?”—who will be able to answer such a question: an infant, an adolescent, an adult or a senior citizen? Surely, any of them can do it but the story told by each of them will be definitely different. Stories are ubiquitous in human culture [1], and they have been part of each of us since early childhood. Young children explore stories in their make-believe and fantasy activities, which they use to start to understand the world that surrounds them, and to explore new situations that are only possible in a fantasy world [22, 26, 33].

For the past few years, several researchers in different research areas have tried to bring stories into the computerised environment. These areas include interactive drama [12, 18, 32], computer games (e.g., The SIMS, Shadow of Memories), intelligent learning environments (e.g., Puppet [11], Kidstory [2] and NICE [24], and pedagogical applications [16]. Each research area has a different goal, which drives application development, and therefore the usage of the story concept is definitely different from application to application. However, everyone aims at benefiting from the fact that stories are part of what makes us human [8].

Following the perspective of Mott et al. [4], due to the explorative and complex nature of narrative, an intelligent learning environment can make use of narrative to promote several kinds of activities for children:

  • Co-construction: participate in the construction of the narrative.

  • Exploration: engage in active exploration of the narrative by trying to understand and reason about the characters’ behaviour.

  • Reflection: engage in consequent analysis of what happened within the story.

In this paper, we present an approach, which is based on the premise that story and narrative may emerge from characters’ interactions during the story creation activity, but such characters may either act autonomously or be controlled by children. Since we position our research in an educational context, we argue that in such creation activities children’s thoughts and needs must be respected and contribute directly to the achievement of the story. Therefore, children should be provided with some support and guidance directives to help them to better understand and reflect on the role-taking situations they experience during such activity.

To prove the validity of such an approach an open architecture was developed – the Support And Guidance Architecture (SAGA)—which does not see each child only as a spectator of the story, but asks her to put herself in the skin of a story character, and together with other children, create their own story. Each child has the possibility of directing a character and her character’s directives not only influence the story but also contribute to its creation. In addition, children are also asked to reflect upon their actions: what (and why) the characters are doing? what are they thinking? and, what children think about their character’s thoughts?

The major goal of developing SAGA as an open architecture is to allow other existing applications to take advantage of the features provided by SAGA with a reduced amount of the effort of integration and change. The applications for which SAGA is designed are mainly story creation applications from different domains and contexts (e.g., games, educational software, etc.).

This paper is organised as follows: first, we present some motivation behind the development of SAGA, and then the architecture is explained in detail (first the theory used and then the different components that compose the architecture). The Teatrix application is introduced, followed by the presentation of the set of procedures taken for integrating SAGA with Teatrix. The evaluation study of the integration of SAGA with Teatrix is presented by explaining the setting, procedures and the results obtained. Finally, some conclusions are drawn.

Motivation

With the design and development of SAGA, we aimed not only at devising some design guidance for the achievement of an interactive story creation experience, but also to provide an implemented framework that could be plugged in and used by other existing applications for different domains and contexts (e.g., games, educational software, etc.).

The philosophy behind the development of SAGA followed the premise that every story element defined and used within the architecture can be parameterised by the “ client” application, that is the characters, props, story world, actions that can be performed by the characters, and even the initial story situation can be specified by the application using the services of SAGA.

Although SAGA aims at reaching the largest possible number of target applications, its applicability follows the principle that the story creation activity is done in a collaborative setting in which the children control the story characters. Children have a direct influence on the behaviour of the characters and indirectly on the story world—featuring the concept of agency defined by Murray [20].

To do this, SAGA allows each child to control a character, but it also raises the possibility of having autonomous characters—meaning that some of the characters can be controlled by the architecture itself. This approach merges the actor, author and spectator roles, since children are invited to act in an interactive story along with the other characters, to create/author such story by acting in it and to understand the other characters’ actions—being a spectator—in order to respond to their behaviours. This new concept aims at overcoming one of the typical problems of interactive narratives/stories—the higher degree of freedom that is given to the user to intervene in the narrative flow, the weaker is the power given to the author to decide on the progress of the story [5]—since the users and authors of the story are the same.

The support and guidance mechanism provided by SAGA features two different dimensions: role-based and emotional.

On the one hand, the role-based support centres itself on clarifying the reasons behind the behaviours and actions taken by the characters. The goal is to promote the justification and context of the behaviours taken by the characters (system or child-controlled) during the story progression. This justification aims at providing the children with some meaning-making and meaning-finding [3] about what happens inside the character’s mind.

On the other hand, the character’s emotional support is strongly related to the role-based dimension, since the emotional state of a character reflects the successful or unsuccessful achievement of its goals, that is, the character’s behaviour complies or not with its assigned role. If a child-controlled character is unhappy with the successful achievement of its goals, this may mean that the child does not agree with the role assigned to her character and she might benefit from some support and guidance. In most cases, the support and guidance mechanism triggers a reflection moment, in which the children are asked to comment on the character’s behaviour in the story or to reflect upon the other characters’ behaviour. Based on the classifications given by the children, the architecture tries to adapt the character’s behaviour and positioning within the story.

Further, it is evident that there is an additional need to support and guide the children during the dramatic game, to help them to engage deeply during story creation and to consider the extent to which children are actually present in the story. By supporting and motivating children to reflect about their characters’ actions within the story world, the goal is to show children that more than influencing the flow of the story with their characters’ directives within the story, the system cares about them [25], and tries to support and help them in order to provide them with a more engaging story creation activity.

In the next section, we present the architecture and its major components, in parallel with the explanation about its functioning and theory applied within it.

Support and guidance architecture

SAGA was developed as an open architecture that can receive information from the story creation application, in real-time, and process such information and suggest some support and guidance directives back to the application.

The definition of an open architecture within this thesis stands for a software architecture, which allows the usage of its services by any story creation application that follows the interface rules defined by it—this definition follows the concept of software architecture of a system. However, there is not a standard or a unanimously accepted definition of what characterises the software architecture of a system, during the past few years there have been several contributions from different researchers in the software engineering field. One of the concepts that played an important role in the definition of our concept of an open architecture was the concept proposed by Booch et al. [4]. The approach taken while devising SAGA was similar to the one proposed by Booch and started with the identification of what were the major competences that it should encompass. The competences identified are:

  • The ability to interact with a visualisation module, by receiving and sending information from and to it—playing the role of a facilitator. Footnote 1

  • The ability to perform the role of a dynamic scriptwriter, that is, to dynamically generate an open script for the story being created by the children.

  • The ability to direct, but not command, the children during the story creation process, giving support directives, which may help the children to indirectly stay in character during the story creation process.

  • The ability to promote reflection during the story creation process, in order to provide a better understanding of the roles being played by the characters and of the commands given by the children.

From this set of competencies it was possible to define the set of structural elements that compose our system: the facilitator, the scriptwriter, the director and the reflection engine (see Fig. 1).

The development of SAGA was based on the assumption that the story creation process is constituted by two distinct phases: story definition/preparation and story construction (de facto). In the first phase the children would define the basic elements for their story: the cast and setting, and in the second they build their collaborative story. To integrate SAGA in any story creation application, it is necessary that the latter complies with two important properties:

  1. 1.

    To be observable—SAGA must be able to inspect the state of the application and also

  2. 2.

    To allow changes—SAGA must be able to introduce new elements in the story creation application or even to take some actions in the story creation application.

Before starting to explain each of the components that compose SAGA, we first introduce some of the key concepts within the architecture, in order to establish a common understanding before getting into further details.

The Theory of SAGA

One of the most important concepts is that associated with the story. The theory behind the definition of the concept has its roots in Propp’s narrative morphology [23]. The story definition stands for a variable sequence of two different constituents: an initial story situation and variable story schema. The first can be seen as the situation in which the characters and their inter-relations are introduced, the story is situated in terms of temporal and spatial localisation, the initial positioning of the characters, and the definition of the goal of the story. The variable story schema is a sequence of functions Footnote 2—each of them represented by a letter-, which starts with a villainy (A) or with a lack (a), and may develop accordingly along the upper or the lower branch of the schema, meaning that it is characterised: by the existence of a struggle (H) and a victory over the villain (I)—in this case the sequence should start with a villainy; or, by the existence of a difficult task (M) and the solution of such a task (N)—in this case the sequence should start with a lack.

$$({\text{A}}|{\text{a}}){\text{BC}} \uparrow {\text{DEFG}}\frac{{{\text{HIK}} \downarrow \Pr - {\text{RsL}}}} {{{\text{LMJNK}} \downarrow \Pr - {\text{Rs}}}}{\text{QExTUW}}$$

where villainy (A): villain causes harm to a member of the family; lack (a): member of the family lacks something, desires something; mediation (B): misfortune made known; hero is dispatched; counteraction (C): hero agrees on a counteraction; departure \((\uparrow)\): hero leaves home; 1st donor function (D): hero tested, receives magical agent or helper; hero’s reaction (E): hero reacts to agent or donor; receipt of agent (F): hero acquires use of magical agent; spatial change (G): hero led to object of search; struggle (H): hero and villain join in direct combat; branding (J): hero is branded or signed; victory (I): villain is defeated; liquidation (K): initial misfortune or lack is liquidated; return (↓): hero returns; pursuit (Pr): hero is pursued; rescue (Rs): hero is rescued from pursuit; unfounded claims (L): false hero presents unfounded claims; difficult task (M): difficult task is proposed to hero; solution (N): task is solved; recognition (R): hero is recognised; exposure (Ex): false hero or villain is exposed; transfiguration (T): hero is given a new appearance; punishment (U): villain is punished; wedding (W): hero is married, ascends the throne;

The next step for the application of this variable story schema is the interpretation of what each function means and how it can be applied in an interactive context. Another important aspect that derives from the application of Propp’s theory is the implicit definition of roles associated with the characters—which are named by him as dramatis personae. Following Propp’s perspective, each of the dramatis personae has a specific set of functions associated, which determines when the character must intervene in the story. The dramatis personae defined by Propp are: villain, donor, helper, princess (and father), dispatcher, hero and the false hero.

After analysing Propp’s narrative structure and examining it with respect to the needs and goals of the architecture, it was possible to come to a simplified version of such variable story schema, with a reduced number of functions and consequently with fewer types of character or dramatis personae.

$$({\text{A}}|{\text{a}}){\text{C}} \uparrow {\text{DEFG}}\frac{{{\text{HJI}}}} {{{\text{MJN}}}}{\text{K}} \downarrow \Pr {\text{RsExUW}}$$

The simplification of the variable story scheme was mostly based on a field study conducted with the aim of analysing children’s written stories. Because this study was not a large-scale one, it can only be understood as an initial exploration and its results can only give us an indication of what kind of functions are most frequently included in children’s stories [14, 15]. Implicitly, it also reduced the number of dramatic personae considered.

Although Propp’s narrative morphology has been adopted as a starting point, it is clear that some of the functions must be adapted to today’s reality and the context of usage. To accomplish this, the concept of function was extended to the concept of plot point—an important moment in the story [17]—and in this way, the formula presented for the variable story schema represents the sequence of plot points that each story should follow—other researchers also using the morphology defined by Propp adapt it to their context of usage [27]. Each plot point is then represented by a set of generic goals, and each of them is equally valid for reaching the particular plot point. For example the plot point villainy can be decomposed into five different generic goals: theft, kidnapping someone, casting of a spell, imprisonment or order to kill someone. Although, these different generic goals are quite specific and folktale-oriented, it is always possible to generalise them and apply them to a more realistic and modern context.

Each generic goal is translated into a plan that guarantees the achievement of the plot point. Each plan is a hierarchical representation of goals and actions—similar to—that is, which can be decomposed into a set of sub-goals and ultimately into a set of atomic actions (the actions performed by the characters in the story world). The planning methodology adopted in SAGA was hierarchical task network (HTN) planning, which is an artificial intelligence (AI) planning methodology that creates plans by task decomposition. HTN planning can be seen as a generalisation of the classical planning problem, where in addition to the primitive actions in the domain, the domain writer also specifies a set of non-primitive actions, and provides schemas for reducing the non-primitive actions into other primitive or non-primitive actions. It is a process where the tasks (non-primitive actions) are decomposed into smaller sub-tasks until primitive actions are found that can be performed directly [10, 30]. Table 1 shows the schema associated with the generic goal, kidnapping someone.

The components of SAGA

The component concept is seen within our architecture as a set of software artefacts for performing a well-defined task and establishing a set of rules for its usage, that is, a public interface. In addition, by defining each of the competences as an independent component, we allow the exchange of such components by others that play a similar role but with a more specific task. The successive steps taken were the definition of the interfaces between these components and the collaboration threads between such components. The components collaborate with each other through a message exchange process. In the following subsections, each of the component is explained in detail by focussing on the main tasks that they have to execute within the architecture.

Facilitator component

The facilitator is the component of SAGA, which establishes the communication between the architecture and the story creation application. As all the components, the facilitator was developed as a stand-alone program that can be invoked remotely and can collaborate with a distributed application. Meaning that each client application, just has to know the facilitator’s IP address, communicates with it through a message-exchange mechanism.

This message-exchanging process is only possible because the architecture provides a set of public methods, which have a well-defined application interface using a clear protocol and have a black-box behaviour, in the sense that they present an identified behaviour to the client application but all the implementation and development decisions are hidden from the latter.

The messages that are exchanged between the facilitator component and the client application are the following:

  • Request information about the story elements: the facilitator component makes inquiries of the application about which story elements have already been chosen within the context of the client application. The story elements refer to the scenes where the story will happen, the cast of characters, which was previously chosen in the client application; the roles associated with those characters, which will determine the behaviours and actions played by the characters and the props that may exist within the scenes. The client application can do this by sending an XML file with the current story elements. If the client application does not fulfil the requirements defined by the architecture, the latter will perform the needed adaptations. This type of message is exchanged before the story creation process starts.

  • Requests the execution of some actions within the client’s context: the facilitator component receives the directives from SAGA and asks the client application to apply them in its context. These directives are related to the actions performed by the characters in the story world—walk, talk, get object; give object and use object, with the placement or introduction of new characters and/or props in the story world and the ability to trigger reflection moments. This exchange of messages happens during the story creation process.

Within the architecture, the facilitator component interfaces and interacts with only two of the other components: the scriptwriter and the director components. Therefore, after having received the information about the story elements the facilitator component sends this information to the scriptwriter component so the architecture can do the rest of the job.

The Scriptwriter

The scriptwriter has as its main goal to build an initial story situation in accordance with the story elements previously chosen by the children. To define the initial story situation, a set of templates was established, and each of them is defined by a set of minimum requisites that must be satisfied to have an initial story situation—the definition of the templates was based on the work of Propp [23]. This set of minimum requisites is defined by: the number and type of characters already specified in the story creation, and, the type of props existing in the story world. Scriptwriter defines two different types of templates:

  • story template with a seeker hero—in this template, the initial story definition is characterised by the presence of the hero character who is assigned with a difficult task, usually a search for a desired entity—starting with the lack (a) plot point, and;

  • story template with a victim hero—this is the case, the story starts with villainy (A) inflicted by the villain on the hero, implying the presence of both characters in the initial story situation.

Additionally, SAGA defines a categorisation on the nature or genre of the story (e.g., mystery, magical or journey). This categorisation reflects the type of situation that is planned for the story and eventually also the type of props that were chosen by the children. Although, the motive can be established at a large-grain size through the type of story template and its category, there is also the need to establish a set of challenges to be discovered throughout the story progression. The scriptwriter is also responsible for adding new characters to the set of story elements sent by the client application, in order to fulfil the requirements of a specific initial story situation. This information is passed to the next component in the form of an XML file.

Narrative Guidance Engine

The narrative guidance engine (NGE) starts its task when it receives the information from the scriptwriter. With the complete information about the elements that constitute the initial story situation and by taking into account the variable story schema (explained in the previous section), the NGE starts to generate the space of all plot points for a particular story template. The generation of the space of all plot points is performed in a phased way. This decision was based on the fact that the space of all plot points is directly proportional to the complexity of the story and that most of those paths turn out to be useless. Therefore, the decision was to perform a kind of just-in-time generation, since at each moment of the story we have to deal with the children’s decisions (since these are the ones directing characters’ actions) and evaluate which is the best path to follow.

To do this, we defined an evaluation function that has to assess, which are the candidates for the next plot point. This evaluation function takes into account several different factors:

  • Which generic goal was chosen for the accomplishment of the previous plot point? For example, if the previous plot point was villainy and if the generic goal associated with it was kidnapping someone, the next possible plot point would be counteraction by the hero character. The counteraction plot point is characterised by a response of the hero character, who must respond to the villainy caused by the villain character. In this case, the counteraction plot point is the next plot point and only the plans associated with the counteraction of a kidnapping are going to be generated;

  • The action already taken since the last plot point (which can be used to match the ones needed to reach one of the next candidates and to understand how many are still needed to conclude it successfully).

By doing this, the evaluation function tries to make sure that the selected path creates a fulfilling experience for the children, in terms of improving their concept of narrative and also providing a rich collaborative experience. It is important to note that although we can delineate an overall structure of the story, the story is defined by the children and stays completely undefined until they start to create it.

Our aim is to try to guide them, in order to guarantee a better understanding of what their roles are in the story and to provide them with any support about what is being felt by the other characters, and why they are performing in the way that they are. This next plot point is communicated to the director agent in the form of a plan.

Director Agent Component

For the specification of the director agent, we established the concept of a narrative agent. This narrative agent uses its sensors to get information from the story world and based on this information decides whether it should provide a change to the story world or to provide some support or guidance to the children, implicitly or explicitly through its actuators. This decision process is performed with the help of the agent’s narrative memory. The narrative memory is organised in the form of episodes and contains information about the story progression from each story character’s point of view. Each episode is constituted from three important events: crisis, climax and resolution [7] and are organised in a temporal sequence and with cause-effect links. At the end of the story creation activity, the director can use the various character-centred stories stored in its memory to generate a unique story that reflects the overall experience of the story creation activity.

In order to perform its task, the director maintains an internal model of the story world and implements a mind associated with each story character Footnote 5. The specification of the rules and functioning of such minds is determined according to the roles played by each character in the story. During the story creation process, the director has four different activities:

  • To update the internal world model and investigate the possibility of generating an episode. To do this, the director agent inspects the characters’ goals in order to find conflicts among characters. When it detects a conflict of goals between two characters, it adds to its memory a new episode in each of their stories. This update task happens whenever the director receives information from the facilitator component.

  • To check whether the current plot point has been achieved, in order to make sure that the story progresses. In case of success the director agent asks the NGE for the next plot point.

  • To check the need to trigger a reflection event. This reflection event happens when there is a conflict between the actions/behaviour performed by the child and her character’s role or a conflict in terms of emotional behaviour—which is detected through the comparison with what the story character is supposed to be doing, that is, the mind of the story character kept by the director. To trigger this reflection event the director asks the reflection engine component to generate an appropriate interaction with the child.

  • To check the need to introduce a new story element (character or object), in order to enrich the story or to overcome some children disagreement with her/his character’s role.

Reflection engine component

The Reflection Engine is the component that on a demand from the director agent generates a reflection moment. The theory behind the design of this component was based on the research of Dorothy Heathcote on acting in classroom drama [3]. The idea is that a child is asked to freeze her character’s actions and explain the meaning of her character’s current behaviour. For Wagner [3] reflection is important because “... is what makes the knowing something that can be touched and assimilated for later use. Feeling without reflection may simply be experienced and forgotten; with reflection it can become an insight, an understanding that makes possible later modification of behaviour in the real world”.

Each reflection moment has a statement about what a specific character has done, which tries to make the children think and justify their agreement/disagreement with this statement. The justifications are done through the selection of three different levels of agreement: fully agree, agree and disagree. The sentences presented in the reflection moments are divided into three different categories: personality, behaviour and emotional (see Table 2 for examples of sentences in each of these categories). The definition of these categories was mainly driven by the opportunities they raise to intervene and provide guidance to the children.

The reflection engine receives from the director agent, the information about the type of conflict that generated the need of a reflection moment. Based on this information, the reflection engine decides which category of reflection should be used. It is important to note that the sentences presented to the child do not only have to refer to his/her character, but can also refer to any other character of the story. By this way, it is possible to understand the child’s opinion about his/her character performance and also his/her opinion about the performance of the other characters. A reflection moment can be composed of one or more interactions.

The analysis of the answers provided by the child is done by the reflection engine, which informs the director agent of the result. This result can assume two different forms:

  • Indicate that the child is not happy with the role of his/her character—in this case the director agent must introduce a new story element and define another role for the child’s character.

  • Indicate that the child understood that the character was not performing according to its role but there is some evidence (collected from the answers of the child) that he/she will modify the control directives of the character.

After having explained the theory applied in SAGA and the role of each component within the architecture, in the next section we introduce Teatrix—a collaborative virtual environment for story creation, which was integrated with SAGA.

Teatrix

Teatrix is a collaborative virtual environment for story creation, which aims to provide effective support for young children developing:

  • Their notions of narrative, through the dramatization of several situations.

  • Their ability to take a second and third person perspective across the experience of a wide range of situations.

Teatrix is an application developed under the NIMIS (Networked Interactive Media In Schools) project, which was an EU-funded FET i3 project under the Experimental School Environments (ESE) program. The application was developed as a three-phased application, and each of them are explained in detail, in the following subsections.

Backstage Phase

In the backstage phase, children can prepare the scenes; choose the props and characters for their story in a way quite similar to what happens in the backstage of a theatre during the preparation of a play. They visually select the scenes they want in their story (by picking from a list of scenes available), link them, and place within those scenes their chosen characters and props (which can also be chosen from a list of characters and props available). The links that are established between the scenes represent the paths the characters can take during the performance—in the on-stage phase (these links are graphically represented by the red lines connecting two different scenes).

In this phase, children have three different sets of pre-defined story elements that they can drag and drop into their story (see Fig. 2). To choose the characters, children have to first select the actors, from a pre-defined set, that make part of the cast and assign to each of them a role to play in the story. The role definition follows the character types defined by Propp [23], and more precisely the changes and simplifications presented in this paper.

Further, the graphical representation of the roles was also designed with the children’s help and suggestions (see Fig. 3). After attributing a role to an actor, the cast has to be placed inside the scenes. The positioning of props and characters inside a scene corresponds to their positioning in the initial story situation—for further details on the character’s architecture developed within Teatrix see [13]. From this phase, the application creates an internal file with the story setup, which can be then used in the second phase of Teatrix.

On-stage phase

Once the setting up phase is done, the children may select one of the stories’ setups to start the acting phase (on-stage performance). Since this phase of Teatrix is a collaborative one, each child participating in the story performance must select the character he/she wants to control. Each child controls/directs a character during the story creation process. All characters that are not chosen by the group of children automatically become autonomous characters. After having chosen the characters, children are ready to start their performances, which will take place in a collaborative 3D-world (see Fig. 4).

To control her character, the child has a set of atomic actions available from which she chooses and then orders her character to do. The direct orders that the child is able to ask her character to perform are for example: walk to <object>, use <object>, talk to <character>, activate <object>, give <object> and get <object>. The available actions depend on the props that the characters possess, since only by using the objects in the world can the characters manage to perform an action.

In this case virtual reality technology plays an important role, because it provides the children with the means to explore the scenarios during story creation [24]. Story creation only evolves if the children work together to achieve a common goal: their story. When the story finishes, children save the result as a kind of “movie”, which they can analyse and even reconstruct for future performances. According to Papert [21], children get much more from an interaction or experience if at the end they create a meaningful artefact, which they can exhibit as a proof of their personal or collaborative work.

Audience Phase

This third option is based on the movie produced in the previous phase. In the audience phase, children can be the audience of their own performances, and experience the story from other characters’ point of view. This change of perspective is quite interesting for the children, since it may reveal some parts of the story that happened in a different scene that they did not have the chance to experience (see Fig. 5).

Here the children also have the possibility to write about the stories that have been previously performed. The writing activity is done with the support of some sequenced snapshots taken during the story performance (see Fig. 6).

Educational Achievements of Teatrix

Teatrix was the target of several small empirical studies and some informal evaluations [13], which showed that although children were quite enthusiastic about using the application there were problems attaining a complete knowledge and awareness of the role-taking situations that occurred during the story creation process and a complete understanding of the actions being taken by the other characters in the story and also an understanding of the emotions raised from those actions. These limitations suggested that some changes were needed and because SAGA was being developed in parallel with Teatrix, there was the opportunity to benefit from the synergies between the two research projects.

By analysing the flaws in Teatrix it was possible to identify that although children valued the interaction established between the story characters, sometimes they were carried away by what happened in the moment and easily forgot what the main task was: to build a story. In the light of this conclusion, it was clear that the support and guidance provided by SAGA would probably be an added-value to Teatrix.

Integration of SAGA within Teatrix

The integration of SAGA with Teatrix was not a very difficult task because they have some theoretical issues in common like the influence of Propp’s morphology, the collaborative nature of the story creation activity performed in the second phase, on-stage option and also the existence of the two-phase philosophy for the creation of a story: the story definition and the story construction.

The points of integration mainly focussed on four different issues:

  1. 1.

    The translation of the story setup file produced in Teatrix, at the end of the Backstage phase.

  2. 2.

    The possibility of receiving information about what happened within Teatrix’s environment—the story world.

  3. 3.

    The possibility of sending action directives to Teatrix’s environment.

  4. 4.

    The introduction of the reflection moments.

The first integration issue was overcome by developing a small application that translated an XML file with a story structure produced in Teatrix into another XML file that obeyed the rules defined by SAGA. The second and third integration issues were solved by integrating an agent within Teatrix’s environment, which had two major functions:

  • To sense the story world and transmit such information to the facilitator component.

  • To act, through its effectors—which were defined according to the specification of Teatrix, in the story in order to accommodate the action directives sent by the facilitator component.

The last integration issue, and maybe the most important one, was solved by introducing a new interface within Teatrix, which was called the hot-seating tool. This new tool integrates the reflection moments, and provided the opportunity to address children in order to promote a better understanding about their characters’ actions within the story (see Fig. 7). It is through this interface that SAGA interacts and receives information about each child’s view of what is happening in the story. Whenever this interface appears to the child the story creation process ends—this is similar to freezing the actions being carried out by the other characters.

Evaluation studies

To evaluate the new outcomes that come from the integration of SAGA with Teatrix, an evaluation study was conducted in a Portuguese school, O Nosso Sonho, which is a non-curricular school. This school organises its main educational activities within different rooms. In each of the different rooms, there are differentiated spaces where various activities take place simultaneously, in accordance with the choice and interest of the children. The evaluation study was conducted during the school year of 2001–2002, with a group of six children aged between 8 and 11 years old (three girls and three boys).

In this evaluation study, we started by introducing the application and provided some help to overcome some initial problems. During the first month, children had training/tutorial sessions with the help of a researcher. In these sessions, children had the opportunity to familiarise themselves with the application and to get some proficiency in how to use the application (they worked in pairs).

In the second phase of the evaluation, a more structured and pre-defined task was introduced in which the children were asked to create a story in Teatrix from a pre-defined story setup. This second phase of the evaluation was composed of three different threads, which meant as well three different stories, and three different story setups. The definition of these story setups was based on Harry Potter stories, because the plot and theme of such stories is well accepted and known by the children. It was interesting to note that the success of Harry Potter stories gave the children an extra interest to participate in the study, mainly because they felt they were creating their own Harry Potter stories—with their own characters.

In these threads, children would participate in groups of three (or two) and each group had the chance to choose which character they wanted to control during the story creation activity. This second evaluation phase was performed inTeatrix‘s second option—the on-stage phase. During this phase, it was decided to maintain the same sequence of tasks/steps, which was the following:

  1. 1.

    Introduction of the new story to be developed

  2. 2.

    Interaction with software application, Teatrix;

  3. 3.

    Interviewing children.

Due to the contemporaneous nature of our research, we opted to apply a case-study methodology. In this evaluation study, we followed an approach that merges Yin’s and Eisenhardt’s perspectives [6, 34], since we started by defining a set of research questions, but we also contemplated the possibility of refining such research questions and even add new ones during the development of the study. To define such research questions, we considered the following research areas: empathy, role taking and role-playing. Besides grounding the definition of the research questions raised in this evaluation study, these may also provide us with some theoretical basis for analysis of the data collected.

The concepts of empathy, role-play and role taking are major ingredients in the research area of Drama Education. From Heathcote’s definition of educational drama [3], it is possible to envision its application in our research domain, that is, the product of the integration of SAGA with Teatrix application is a collaborative environment in which the children engage in active role-taking situations. The rules to take part in such situations are not pre-defined, since children act only in response to:

  • What they feel in that moment

  • What they are expected to do in those situations (role-play)

  • What the others do and finally

  • How the others felt in response to others’ actions.

By leaving the plot undetermined, we provide children with the opportunity to feel tension in the form of a problem, a challenge that must be solved, a threat, a question. From this tension, they move to the recognition of the problem and its implications, which would lead to a cognitive and affective response. In Heathcote’s opinion, emotion is at the heart of the drama experience, but each child should be kept in a safe position, like the self-spectator, which remains safely protected because it is a drama experience but at the same time both engaged and detached.

By experiencing the emotions conveyed in the drama experience, children can experience an empathic relation with the story and with its characters, and they can go through the three different levels of accomplishment identified by Stein and Thompson [28, 29], which means that they can watch the experience of others in the drama experience—even if he/she is the one playing one role, what is happening within the drama is not happening with him/her but with his/her character, the child can then transpose himself/herself to the place of the character in order to understand the character’s experience, and finally to react in accordance to his/her interpretation of the experience. The ability to transpose oneself into the place of the character is realised in SAGA through the triggering of a reflection moment, which aims at providing the children with the opportunity to reflect about what is happening with her character or with the other characters.

In these reflection moments, SAGA assumes the position of a role-player leader, and debates with the children the content and reasons behind the actions taken by the characters within the story. This kind of debriefing may equip the children with a more flexible way of thinking and understanding of what the others do. These role-taking and role-playing activities are not only hoped to develop the children’s empathic behaviour, but also provide them with the possibility to relate the lessons learnt from the drama experiences to real life situations.

From these domains that mingle in so many ways, it is possible to define the following research questions:

  • Does the product of SAGA and Teatrix promote a transfer of emotions?

  • Do children understand the roles of their characters?

  • Is there an understanding of the role played by the other characters?

  • Is there an understanding of the emotions experienced by the other characters?

After having established the research questions, and following Yin’s methodology [34], it is important to establish a set of units of analysis that guided the data collection. In Table 3, the units of analysis are presented.

These units of analysis were used during the observations of the interactions with the application and for the definition of the structure of the post-interaction interviews. The data-collection task was achieved from two different sources: direct observation and post-interaction interviews.

The direct observation method played an important role during the conducting of this case study evaluation, since it allowed the researcher to collect some data related to ambience conditions and behaviour patterns that took place during the interactions with the application. Through this method it was also possible to capture each child’s opinion about the software, especially their comments after news features had been added. During the second phase of evaluation, the direct observation method took the form of participant observation, since the researchers doing the evaluation played different roles not only during the study, but also in the classroom’s usual activities. Nevertheless, the researchers always had in their minds that they needed to keep some distance in order not to put in risk the evaluation being carried. The interviews assumed the form of focussed interviews, which allowed the researcher to have a set of pre-defined questions—basically, a set of guidelines—and to elaborate on these questions when the targets provided different opinions on the matters being asked. By elaborating on the questions, it is possible to detect other factors that may influence the situation being studied.

The data collected was then analysed by using the content analysis method, which followed an approach derived from cognitive science. This approach includes the creation of decision maps and mental models. These decision maps attempt to represent the relationships between ideas, beliefs, attitudes, and information available to the researcher when making a decision within a text. Mental models are groups or networks of inter-related concepts that are thought to reflect conscious or sub-conscious perceptions of reality. To do this, we analysed the data collected and converted the text obtained from the direct observation and the interviews into a map of concepts and relations.

Following, we present each of the units of analysis and a set of examples, taken from the data collection, and the relations and hypothesis that we established from them:

Reference to directives given by the child to the character and relation to the role played

  • Examples:

    • JP suggests that they could talk to the other character.

    • M in control of the action catches the wooden stick and a magical wand.

    • They try to catch the objects they encounter (...)

    • JP says: “Hit him with the wooden stick”!

    • M answers: “Wait, it isn’t working so let’s pick up this mushroom and we then try again”.

    • M catches all the magical wands she finds. Then she discovers a mushroom and asks JP “Should I catch it”?

    • “I am going to catch that magical wand, right now”!

    • A says: “I cannot catch this”!, she speaks about the wooden stick that becomes visible in the world.

    • JA says: “This is difficult to catch”!, he shuts up and looks at A who tries to catch the wooden stick.

    • A and AJ have used one of the objects on Mauzão and they hear a bell-like sound (...)

    • A suggests: “Mauzão must have caught the magical wands, so let’s offer him some mushrooms”!

    • A says: “Give me the mouse”! After getting it back she manages to catch the last magical wand and the story ends.

    • R continues: “The mushroom ... someone has already caught it”. “Oh, oh! Someone has also caught the other magical wand! Because I heard the sound of someone catching something”!

    • N moves in the chair, blinks, raises his hand and says: ”We have caught the third one! We win”!

    • R—Because she always caught the magical wands.

    • R—To catch the magical wand. A—It was our goal, of course!!

    • Jo—He shot Inês ...

    • He caught a magical wand, and we used the magical wand on our character and also on Inês. The mushroom was the magical potion and we caught that too. And because we caught it the story ended.

    • We had to catch the mushroom—which was the magical potion—and find the magical wand.

    • We had to help the teacher to catch the magical wands but it was too easy.

    • He defeated the bad guy because he was fast and caught the magical wands.

  • Interpretation: Most of the times children direct their character to walk, catch prop or to use prop. By analysing each of the stories, it is possible to contextualise these actions, and conclude that in most of the occasions children use them to accomplish the role that has been assigned to their character. This may imply that they did understand what their character’s role was, within each story, and tried to direct it inline with such role.

Comments/opinions about character’s performance

  • Examples:

    • R “Slow girl... ”(referring to his character)

    • “Look, she is moving, but she is not running.”

    • M “She is so slow”!—she looks at the screen.

  • Interpretation: From the examples gathered for this unit of analysis, one can conclude that sometimes children were a little disappointed with the performance of their character. This disappointment is not directly related to the character’s capabilities to act in the story but to the performance of the application itself.

Reference to actions played by the other characters and further relation to the role played by them

  • Examples:

    • A shakes her head negatively and says: “She may be hiding here”—she moves the camera and tries to see behind a tree.

    • N says: “She may be on top of the tree”!

    • Children alternate in the control of their character and talk to each other: “And if we have chosen the other character? What would its goal be? Would we also have to catch the magical potion”?

    • JP looks at M and says: “You cannot give mushrooms to Mauzão because he likes mushrooms, we have to catch them to negotiate with him”.

    • A asks “This means that Mauzão likes mushrooms? Oh God, just go ... just run away”. She says this to AJ who is now in control of the mouse. A suggests: “Mauzão must have caught the magical wands, so let’s offer him some mushrooms”!

    • N is in control of the mouse and says: The bad guy won’t catch us”!!

    • R continues: “The mushroom ... someone has already caught it”. “Oh, oh! Someone has also caught the other magical wand! Because I heard the sound of someone catching something”!

    • N says: “Catch the mushroom also”!, “It caught the wooden stick by himself, it wasn’t me or R caught it”—at this point N doesn’t understand that Tobias, the other character had given him a wooden stick because it may be needed to face Mauzão—misunderstanding.

    • R—What I liked the most was when Pedro was after us and started to hit us, again and again!!

    • A—Maybe because he was our rival. Because he was the villain.

  • Interpretation: The examples show that children were, in most of the cases, aware of what the other characters were doing and of the implications that those actions would have towards their character. From the examples, it is possible to realise that when facing the other characters—in most of the cases such characters played the rival role—they acted quite enthusiastically and they were quite engaged in the interactions. In addition, whenever they address such a character the expressions used transmitted some identification between children and their character, in the sense that what happened to their character happened also to them, and their character’s tasks would be their own tasks. Further, it is also possible to find some actions, or even consequences of some actions that are not possible within the software but which are imagined or interpreted by the children, such as: N says: “she may be on top of the tree”! This kind of interpretation happened not only in the beginning of the study, mostly because children think that in such an application it is possible to do everything.

Reference to emotions felt by the character or to any actions that may be used to deduct or imply its emotional state

  • Examples: Not found.

  • Interpretation: In this case, it was not possible to find any evidences that would give us any information about this unit of analysis. In our view, this may happen because the graphical representation of the character in Teatrix application is achieved by using 2D-sprites, which do not allow facial expressiveness. In order to overcome such a limitation the emotional expression was introduced within the hot-seating tool, but this would imply that children would have to open a window in order to know their character’s emotional state or the other characters’ emotional state.

Reference to the child’s emotional state or any form of corporal expression that may be used to imply such emotional state

  • Examples:

    • He says: “Ah, Ah”! gets up quite energetically, and keeps smiling. MA smiles, J sits again and gets closer to the screen.

    • J looks to his colleagues and says: “oops”!

    • J “I cannot, do you think that we can do everything you want”?!

    • Looks at his colleagues with an astonishing and smiling expression.

    • J looks and smiles when he sees the characters walking in the screen, he looks back to the researcher smiling and saying: it happened!! Opens his arms looking at the screen!—a sign of victory.

    • A says: “Oh, oh... the dark side”!!

    • Both look curiously at the screen.

    • JP also gets up. Both look at the big screen with a thoughtful look.

    • Because they have caught the three magical wands, the story finishes. Both of them smile and cheer each other.

    • By moving the camera A looks for the magical wand and AJ says: “It’s enough”!, and smiles.

    • N moves in the chair, blinks, raises his hand and says: ”We have caught the third one! We win”!

    • R says: “Oh, I am sad ...the story is over”!

  • Interpretation: From the examples collected, it is possible to imply different emotional states of the children. Children are quite enthusiastic about the story and their involvement with their character and story is high, which sometimes is translated into joy and happiness when they manage to achieve the story goal and other times is translated into disappointment and some exasperation when they cannot do what they want. Additionally, it is possible to find one example of one child that was quite sad right after his character had achieved its goal—meaning that although everything happened as it should, the child was not satisfied with the length of the story and its degree of complexity. It was also possible to identify some occasions where children were quite focused on what they were doing.

The results obtained show that:

  • In terms of transfer of emotions from the story, in particular from the character to the children controlling such character, it was possible to identify some children’s behaviours, which showed that they were happy when their characters successfully achieved a challenge in the story, and in opposition they were quite sad and angry when another character did something bad to their character.

  • It was also possible to conclude that children understood the roles of their characters, meaning that the directives that they gave them were meaningful for the achievement of the role played by them. However, sometimes they expressed some disappointment with the performance of their characters, since they wanted them to “run” not to simply walk.

  • The interactions promoted between characters also showed that they stayed in character, and that in most of the cases children understood not only their character’s role in the story but also the role of the other characters of the story. However, there is evidence that at least in two different occasions children were mistaken about the role played by another character (Example: “N says: “catch the mushroom also”!, “It caught the wooden stick by himself, it wasn’t me or R caught it”—at this point N doesn’t understand that Tobias, the other character had given him a wooden stick because it may be needed to face Baddy—misunderstanding”.).

  • Relating to the issue about feeling the emotions of the characters, it was not possible to find any evidence on this issue. The reasons behind this, as has been stated before may be connected with the technical limitations of the application (Teatrix). On the other hand, in relation to the emotions felt by the children, there was some evidence that showed that children’s emotions go from a positive to a negative pole when their character succeeds or does not succeed to overcome a difficult task.

Conclusions

In this paper we presented a different approach to the application of the story and narrative concepts within intelligent learning environments. With this approach we aim to provide new opportunities to children to explore different situations, engage in role-taking and role-playing situations, which provide them with inline reflection opportunity that would help them to act in those situations or in future ones.

Our approach was implemented in the form of an open architecture, which aims at providing already existent story creation applications with a support and guidance mechanism. This support and guidance mechanism is achieved through the integration of different components in SAGA, which have different roles throughout the story creation activity such as a dynamic scriptwriter, an NGE, a drama manager and a reflection engine.

When comparing the children’s experiences with Teatrix- by itself, and with Teatrix and SAGA, it is possible to conclude that a better job is done by the product of the integration of both applications, since there are some results that indicate that children have a better understanding of the role-taking and role-playing situations they engage in, and by analysing the story creation process it is also possible to conclude that children did not limit to interact with the other characters, they had a main task to carry out, the story and achieving its main goal.

The results of the integration of SAGA with Teatrix application cannot be understood as conclusive evidence of the benefit of SAGA, but as some encouraging results suggest that SAGA can produce similar results with other applications. In the near future, there is the possibility to study the integration of SAGA with a commercial application from Lego.
